article.description:
Just when the Texas Longhorns thought they
had seen everything from T.J. Ford, he found more ways to leave
them gasping.
article.headline: Ford scores career-high 25 points in victory
article.linkText: Ford sparks No. 4 Texas to rout with his scoring
article.story: AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- Just when the Texas Longhorns thought they had seen everything from T.J. Ford, he found more ways to leave them gasping. Already one of the best passing guards in the country, Ford scored a career-high 25 points with an array of pull-up jumpers, layups and one thunderous dunk Saturday night to send No. 4 Texas to an 89-61 win over Texas A&M. Ford, who spent the offseason taking thousands of shots each day to improve a suspect shooting touch, scored from nearly everywhere on the court against the Aggies. It was his breakaway dunk that left its biggest mark on this one. At 5-foot-10, Ford is the Longhorns' shortest player -- and the quickest. With Texas leading 67-45 with eight minutes left, he started a fastbreak with a steal and capped it with an eye-popping tomahawk dunk that brought the Erwin Center crowd of 15,060 to its feat and sealed A&M's fate. "It felt real good,'' Ford said. "I want to see the replay to see how it was. I want to see if it was better than the last one.'' The "last one'' was his unexpected throw down off a missed 3-pointer that helped spark the 'Horns to a win at Baylor earlier in the week. Jason Klotz added 15 points and James Thomas had 16 rebounds for Texas (12-2, 3-0 Big 12), which has won seven in a row since losing at then-No. 1 Arizona on Dec. 15. The Longhorns have also won 27 of the last 30 in the series with Texas A&M. Bernard King led the Aggies (9-5, 1-2) with 16 points. But this game was all about Ford and his ability to shoot from the outside, something he's not always been able to do. Ford was 9-of-16 from the floor, 7-of-7 from the foul line and had six steals before leaving with 3:51 left and Texas up 76-50. "When he starts making shots, we're a hard team to guard,'' Texas coach Rick Barnes said. "He just has a great feel for the game.'' Aggies coach Melvin Watkins was impressed. "All you have to do is look at the stat sheet. It speaks for itself,'' Watkins said. "He makes people around him better. That's what good point guards do and he's one of the best in the country.'' Ford struggled through some early season miscues and shooting misfires, but has been a force since Big 12 play started. "You could just tell there was a difference in terms of his focus,'' Barnes said. "I think he knows what he wants to do.'' As electric as Ford was, both teams got off to an ugly start. The first 12 minutes saw a combined 11-of-33 shooting, 17 turnovers and 13 fouls. Texas finally got untracked when Brian Boddicker hit the Longhorns' only 3-pointer of the first half for a 17-12 lead. Ford sparked a 14-2 run that made it 31-14 with seven straight points on two long jumpers and a 3-point play. Texas led 43-28 at halftime after King banked in a 3-pointer from midcourt as the first-half buzzer sounded. King scored seven straight points to open the second half as A&M cut the lead to 44-35 before Ford hit another jumper and Thomas' basket put Texas back up by 13. King scored 30 on the Longhorns' homecourt last year, but picked up his fourth foul with 14:32 left and went to the bench. He seemed to take the Aggies' scoring punch with him. Ford hit another jumper and finished a fastbreak with a layup before Royal Ivey made it 59-39 with 12:01 to play.
